thread.title: Liverpool vs Tottenham, Jurgen Klopp v Mauricio Pochettino
thread.title_full: Liverpool vs Tottenham, Jurgen Klopp v Mauricio Pochettino | Daily Mail Online

author: Jonny Singer for MailOnline
title: Liverpool vs Tottenham, Jurgen Klopp v Mauricio Pochettino

organizations.name: jordan henderson vs victor wanyama liverpool

text:
Separated by just four points and three places in the Premier League , Liverpool and Tottenham go into Saturday's Anfield clash with everything to play for.
A win for Mauricio Pochettino's side would not only lift them seven points clear of their rivals, it would also continue Liverpool's terrible form in 2017.
But if Jurgen Klopp's men were to turn things around and take a victory, it would close the race for Champions League football once again.
Sportsmail takes a look at the key tactical battles.
Jurgen Klopp and Mauricio Pochettino will go head to head again at Anfield on Saturday
The press gangs
Both Klopp and Pochettino love their sides to press, but it's two quite different systems which they enact.
The two sides' relentless work rate is reflected in their stats, with both of them at the bottom of the table for the number of interceptions they have to make per game.
Tottenham average just eight in a match, while Liverpool are 19th in the league with 10 per match - because both win the ball with tackles in their opponent's half before they can pass it out.
That should make for an interesting match-up. Spurs will harry Liverpool high up the pitch, would could make it difficult for the hosts to play out from the back, as they like to do.
The power and energy of Mousa Dembele in the Spurs midfield could be crucial at Anfield
The relentless energy of Vincent Wanyama and Mousa Dembele, coupled with the dynamism of the three behind Harry Kane, should see Spurs trouble Liverpool in midfield - but if the Reds can break through that press their dangermen will cause the defence problems.
The power of that midfield, and their ability to drop deep to collect the ball while ball-playing defenders beat the onrushing forwards with clever passing, is one of the key ways Spurs can break Liverpool's zonal pressing.
Attack vs Defence
This game features the Premier League's best attack and the league's best defence, but there is a reason that neither is challenging for the title - they both struggle at one end of the pitch.
Tottenham boast the meanest defence, having conceded only 16 times this season - Liverpool's 30 is almost twice as many!
Liverpool are the league's top scorers, but Hugo Lloris and Spurs have conceded the fewest
But Spurs haven't been brilliant going forward. Their 46 goals scored is the lowest in the top five, while their only goal in the past two league games was a penalty. Without Kane, and without spot kicks, they would really be in trouble.
Liverpool, in contrast, are the league's top scorers, with 52, the same number as Arsenal, but they let far too many in. In part it is their system to blame, but individual defensive and goalkeeping errors have also cost them.
Without Harry Kane's goals Tottenham might be in trouble, but they are defensively solid
Contrast in form
On New Year's Day, Liverpool were four points ahead of Tottenham, having just beaten Manchester City and on a run of four straight wins.
Spurs were beginning to recover from a winter blip in November and December, but were still some way off the pace.
Fast forward six weeks and Liverpool haven't won in the league since, while Spurs are flying. Nine wins and two draws in their last 11 games for the north London side have seen them up to second, while Liverpool's three points from five games in 2017 have resulted in a slide to fifth.
Liverpool have picked up just three Premier League points in five games in 2017
Key battles
Toby Alderweireld vs Roberto Firmino
Liverpool's attack relies on plenty of fluid movement, whether Firmino leads the line or Klopp opts for another striker. Whether Alderweireld tracks the Brazilian, or hands him on to one of the deeper midfielders, could dictate the shape of Spurs' defence.
Kyle Walker vs Philippe Coutinho
Another question to be asked of the visiting side - will Walker, one of the best right backs in the league this season, be able to cope with Coutinho? The Brazil star loves to come in off the left, but if Walker goes forward, as he loves to do, Coutinho may not be the best man to track him. This could be the most intriguing match-up of the contest.
Klopp will rely on Philippe Coutinho to provide the spark, especially if Adam Lallana is out
Harry Kane vs Joel Matip
So much of what is good about Spurs is typified by Kane - work ethic, efficiency and passion in abundance. But in their last four games, Tottenham have only managed two goals not scored by Kane, and he assisted one of those, so keep him quiet and they may struggle. Matip has had a woeful 2017 - missing out on Cameroon's Africa Cup of Nations triumph, and not recording a win with Liverpool. He will have extra motivation to turn it around, and will have his hands full on Saturday.
Sadio Mane vs Ben Davies
Liverpool's attack sorely missed Mane's pace and direct running while he was in Gabon last month, but his return hasn't yet sparked the turnaround they would have hoped for. But with Danny Rose out, Mane might sense an opportunity to get Liverpool going again. Expect Wanyama and Dembele to spend a lot of their afternoon helping Davies out.
Jordan Henderson vs Victor Wanyama
Liverpool's midfield has not been great in recent weeks, with Emre Can coming under pressure for his place alongside Henderson. Whether Georginio Wijnaldum comes in or not, the home side will have a tough time against Spurs' deep-lying duo of Wanyama and Dembele. Unless they can escape the Tottenham shackles, Klopp's side may struggle to get their game going at all.
Jordan Henderson and Emre Can must step up against a strong Tottenham midfield
